content:
By the look of this bug https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=382415

I don't think there is an sort of "recent" or "frequent" selections.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: I'm sure that my Thunderbird did offer the frequently used email addresses first until I turned on the Google CARDDAV sync. It does not work since. @Matt I'm not sure if the bug mentioned above is related to my problem.
creator: jirinkosar

content:
The drop down list is based on best match to your typing entry. The more letters you type the smaller the list becomes as it filters on your typing of email address. The drop down selections of potential matches are sourced from the Thunderbird address books.

I have always found that when you start to type an email address in a TO field, Thunderbird offers a potential list that best matches what you are typing based on current contacts in address books.

So if you sent an email to a person that was not in an address book AND you do not auto save outgoing address in an address book, then if you wanted to create another email to same person they would not be offered in the drop down list.

Example: If you started to type: gmail then observe the list and you should find it lists all the @gmail.com email addresses.

However, the results should be displayed in a popularity order, not necessarilly an alphabetical order.

So the order of what you see in list maybe most frequently and recently used at the top, but the list itself is not strictly a most recent list, it depends upon what you are typing.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Never mind. Issue seems to have resolved itself.

content: Uppercase is difficult to read and implies that you are shouting. When you attempt to send a message, is there an error message? Same for incoming. Any errors? IMAP or POP? What is account, e.g., AOL, gmail, )? What version of Thunderbird are you using? What operating system?

content: Maybe if you share your error messages or whatever, someone here may be able to help. I regret you are having difficulties. Thunderbird is very sensitive to antivirus programs that tend to interrupt updates.

content: I didn't post the error message because there is none. It just keeps working to download forever, but no mail is downloaded.
creator: bryantco

content: The account may be corrupted. I suggest trying to send a message to see if it works. You might also attempt to repair by clicking settings>privacy&security, click saved passwords and then show passwords and then highlight the incoming and outgoing server, rightclick and delele. That would remove passwords and, if that helped, you will be prompted for password to retrieve. That may not do it, but the connection isn't working. Good luck.
creator: davidsk

content: Since you don't remember it, I suggest you contact your email provider to get a new one. You will also need it whenever you move to a new computer in the future.
creator: davidsk

content:
There is a new mail, but it is not in the inbox. Probably in important (it appears to be the common one) the priority inbox settings don't allow for IMAP. Fairly typical of browser based email that offers IMAP really.

The badge defaults to a count of new messages, I think. I turn it off as I really have little interest in the count of the latest download and absolutely none for unread messages as it is always over 99 so offers me nothing. As I do not use that feature, I really don't know what you are seeing there, but it does draw it's information from the folder pane for the unread counts.
creator: MattAuSupport

Change the setting in Google to show them for syncing.

Thank you again!
creator: Seba2000

content:
I think you need to start with the incorrect assumption that Thunderbird uses 587 by default. In a proiperly functioning system with internet access the settings for gmail will be downloaded from here https://autoconfig.thunderbird.net/v1.1/gmail.com Not the port for SMTP is 465.

So if you are having accounts created using anything but the approved configuration (port 465), then clearly Thunderbird is not able to be access that web site address when the account setup commences, hence a guessing game ensues that could result in a "guessed" connection using port 587. But first you need to figure out why Thunderbird can't access it's database to get the correct information. I suggest you look to your antivirus, and internet security suite or a firewall that may be blocking access to the web address.

There was code introduced in V91 to automatically convert gmail SMTP to use oauth. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/automatic-conversion-google-mail-accounts-oauth20 I am however not aware of an instance where someone alleged Thunderbird changed ports used following that conversion. It may be possible that there is an addon that might be messing with your settings. I suggest you look in the troubleshooting information on the help menu under "add-ons" to see if you have any installed, especially ones you don't recognize!

You might post that information (add-ons) and the following Security software segment here once you access it. Others might see something you don't.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Thanks Matt. A little above my “Pay scale”. It’s taken me a few days to understand what you are telling me. Then I had to figure out how to take action.

Well, I have added Thunderbird to the apps allowed through the Firewall. I did notice that Firefox was already allowed.

I can’t figure how to modify Windows Defender.

I have found the Troubleshooting information. (I think)

I have copied it here. It does show the Add-ons. The only add-on that was active was “Manually sort folders” and I have deactivated it. However, I do not think that “Manually sort folders” would be causing a problem.

Joe

I'll post the text of the Troubleshooting Information

It is too large to post in one.

I have 21 screen shots of the page I can post if you like. I can also send it by email.
creator: JoeGons

content:
In a previous question you posted you said "I have EIGHT Gmail accounts"

You seem to have added more since that previous question which was only 10 days ago.

I notice you have 10 gmail accounts and three of them have additional identities - other email addresses that makes a total of 14 gmail email addresses.

It seems very weird that all 14 gmail smtp accounts have set themselves to use port 587 when the default is 465.

I also notice you mentioned : "I am using the Portable version of Thunderbird. 102.9.0 (32-bit)" G:\Thunderbird Portable\App\thunderbird\thunderbird.exe

Profile also stored on G: drive : G:\Thunderbird Portable\Data\profile

For clarity they are listed below. account14:

  • INCOMING: account14, , (pop3) pop.gmail.com:995, SSL, OAuth2
  • OUTGOING: , smtp.gmail.com:587, SSL, OAuth2, true
  • OUTGOING: , smtp.gmail.com:587, SSL, OAuth2, false
  • OUTGOING: , smtp.gmail.com:587, SSL, OAuth2, false

account16:

  • INCOMING: account16, , (pop3) pop.gmail.com:995, SSL, OAuth2
  • OUTGOING: , smtp.gmail.com:587, SSL, OAuth2, true
  • OUTGOING: , smtp.gmail.com:587, SSL, OAuth2, false

account18:

  • INCOMING: account18, , (pop3) pop.gmail.com:995, SSL, OAuth2
  • OUTGOING: , smtp.gmail.com:587, SSL, OAuth2, true
  • OUTGOING: , smtp.gmail.com:587, SSL, OAuth2, false

account23:

  • INCOMING: account23, , (pop3) pop.gmail.com:995, SSL, OAuth2
  • OUTGOING: , smtp.gmail.com:587, SSL, OAuth2, true

account24:

  • INCOMING: account24, , (pop3) pop.gmail.com:995, SSL, OAuth2
  • OUTGOING: , smtp.gmail.com:587, SSL, OAuth2, true

account25:

  • INCOMING: account25, , (pop3) pop.gmail.com:995, SSL, OAuth2
  • OUTGOING: , smtp.gmail.com:587, SSL, OAuth2, true

account32:

  • INCOMING: account32, , (pop3) pop.gmail.com:995, SSL, OAuth2
  • OUTGOING: , smtp.gmail.com:587, SSL, OAuth2, true

account35:

  • INCOMING: account35, , (pop3) pop.gmail.com:995, SSL, OAuth2
  • OUTGOING: , smtp.gmail.com:587, SSL, OAuth2, true

account40:

  • INCOMING: account40, , (pop3) pop.gmail.com:995, SSL, OAuth2
  • OUTGOING: , smtp.gmail.com:587, SSL, OAuth2, true

account43:

  • INCOMING: account43, , (pop3) pop.gmail.com:995, SSL, OAuth2
  • OUTGOING: , smtp.gmail.com:587, SSL, OAuth2, true

That means there are 14 different gmail email addresses. First you need to be absolutely certain that each gmail account and identity is actually using its own smtp. Always check the following via this Outgoing Server list method.

  • Menu icon > Account Settings
  • Scroll to bottom of left pane - below 'Local Folders' and click on 'Outgoing Servers (SMTP)'

All the outgoing servers will get listed in the right pane. you should have one for each email address meaning you have 14 gmail smtp. Q: How many Outgoing gmail smtp servers have you got listed?

  • Post an image showing the list.


Working down from top to bottom for each gmail smtp.

  • Select smtp in list
  • click on 'Edit'.
  • Description: type email address = User Name - this is important.
  • Set Port: 465
  • User Name = full gmail email address.
  • Click on 'OK'

Select next gmail smtp and repeat the same steps. Obviously each smtp will have a different User Name / email address.

If you find one email address does not have it's own smtp then click on 'Add' and enter the correct settings to create another smtp.

Secondly - check that every account and identity are using their own smtp. In Left pane starting at the top and work down for each gmail account.

  • Select name of account
  • Look bottom right for the 'Outgoing Server (SMTP)':
  • The 'Description' entered in each smtp is now useful.
  • Does the Description email address match the same as the selected account ?
  • If no, then click on the drop down and select the correct email address smtp for the account.

DO NOT click on the 'Edit SMTP_Server' button because you could end up editing something that is used by another account. First it is important to check all the account really are using their own smtp server.

If this account has additional identities:

  • click on 'Manage Identities' button
  • select the additional identity and click on Edit
  • Settings tab - look at the bottom for Outgoing Server (SMTP)
  • Check - is that email address identity using the correct smtp ?
  • It must use the one which has Description saying it's for that email identity address.
  • click on the drop down to locate the correct smtp

DO NOT click on the 'Edit SMTP_Server' button.

Repeat the above check on each account and identity, so you are now certain every account is using the correct smtp.

When you have checked and possibly corrected each and every account and identity. Exit Thunderbird Wait a few moments for background processes to complete. Start Thunderbird.

We need to see that all the changes have been saved and are being used on start up.

  • Menu icon > Help > More TRoubleshooting Information
  • Scroll to 'Mail and News' section
  • Copy all the data only in that section and paste into this forum.




These addons are disabled but uninstall them as they are not designed to work with current TB version.

  • ImportExportTools extension version 3.2.1 false
  • LookOut extension version 1.2.13 false

At some point Update:

  • Manually Sort Folders as the latest is version 2.3.0
  • https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-us/thunderbird/addon/manually-sort-folders/
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Thanks Toad-Hall for your very detailed reply. It must have taken quite some time. I will need to tackle each process, one at a time.

First: The multiple identities. Please have a look at this Post.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1408724

I believe that because I removed and restored several accounts, I have a problem with duplicates.

Now, you mentioned the accounts 14, 16 and 18. See the attachment.

You will notice that they have multiple identities but the identities are the same. These are not additional addresses but, for some reason, duplicate and triplicate entries that seem to be the same.

See #18 for example.

Shall I simply remove one? Which one? Using the "Manage Identities"


Thanks. Joe
creator: JoeGons

content:
re:I believe that because I removed and restored several accounts, I have a problem with duplicates.

When you remove a POP account via Account Settings > Account Actions > Remove Account: The Pop account is removed from the Account Settings and also the Folder Pane. But, it is not removed from the Profile Name > 'Mail' folder. Why ? Because Thunderbird realises it was a Pop account and that may mean this is your only copy of downloaded emails which if deleted may be disastrous and cause a loss of emails. It may mean you can recover emails or recover the folder structure saving you a lot of work resorting the Inbox. It is essential that those pop folders do not get auto deleted when a pop account is Removed.

It means when you recreate a POP account, Thunderbird knows you already have a gmail account using pop.gmail.com so it creates another one but adds a number eg: pop.gmail-1.com. However, before downloading any emails into that recreated pop account, you can immediately point that newly recreated account to use the original account folder via the Account Settings > Server Settings > Local directory thus restoring all emails and continuing to use the original set of folders many of which you may have created. Some people may not have auto deleted emails from the server when downloading emails, so the new account will simply redownload everything providing the gmail webmail settings are set up to do it. This means you now have a duplicate set of emails in two separate profile account folders Or if that is not the case you can get copies from the original pop account folder and copy them over to the new account folder.

If you have more than one gmail email address then additional pop accounts using pop server eg: pop.gmail.com; will also get a pop account folder with an extra number.


How to find out which pop.gmail-n.com are you currently using for any particular gmail account:

  • 'Account Settings' > 'Server Settings' for the pop gmail email address/account
  • Bottom right locate: 'Local directory:'

You may need to make the window wider to see all the text in Local directory: But it will say something like this:

  • G:\Thunderbird Portable\Data\profile\Mail\pop.gmail-3.com

In which case do not delete the pop.gmail-3.com folder.

In the profile mail folder, you can delete any pop.gmail-n.com folder that you are not currently using in any of your current pop gmail accounts, but only do this if you are certain those folders do not contain emails you may need to restore. But you may feel there is no point in keeping several pop account folders that contain identical sets of accounts.

re :You will notice that they have multiple identities but the identities are the same. Shall I simply remove one? Which one? Using the "Manage Identities"

Usually, the top one is the default one, it will also have bold font to indicate it is default and it will be the one shown in the left pane of Account Settings.

It seems you created additional identical identities for the same account.

  • Click on 'Manage Identities'
  • Select second in list and click on 'Delete'
  • Click on 'Close'
  • Check the account is still in the Account Settings. It should not get removed.

REgarding the SMTP server settings.

Follow same instructions as previously on how to access the 'Outgoing Server (SMTP)' list. For each gmail smtp - you need one for each mail account/email address.

  • Set 'Description as email address = username'
  • Leave the Port setting as 587
  • Change 'Connection Security' to 'STARTTLS'
  • click on OK

creator: davidsk

content:
re :I've recently migrated from POP3 to IMAP

You cannot simply change the server settings of the pop account over to settings for an imap account. Can you answer a few questions and provide some info?

Did you create the IMAP account as a completely new mail account for the sbcglobal.net email address?

If you create the New > Existing Mail Account for the sbcglobal.net email address and set up as 'Imap' using the yahoo server settings, then you should have been through all the oauth set up already. Did that occur ?

What have you got set up here:

  • Menu icon > Settings > Privacy & Security

Under Passwords section click on 'Saved Passwords' click on 'Show Passwords'

You should see an oauth://account line for the @sbcglobal.net email address = user name. Do you see any other lines for that same @sbcglobal.net email address ? eg: imap://account... mailbox://account... smtp://account...

What do you see ?


Post the following information:

  • Menu icon > Help > More Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Mail and News Accounts' section
  • Upload an image showing all that section OR copy all the data and paste it into this forum question.

We do need to see all the accounts listed to understand whether another settings could be being used on more than one account.


Regarding the link you posted: It should not be using the link you mention because that is for Microsoft and the outlook server and not yahoo. So it is not going to work.


1. Have you got any program on your computer which is using the localhost maybe to update webpages on a website etc eg: Apache ? If yes, then you need to switch it off. Once oauth has been created then you can switch it back on.

2. Are you using a VPN ? If yes, then switch it off or create a Tunnel so that Thunderbird can use Tunnel bypassing the VPN.


3. Have you set up Thunderbird to allow cookies ? Check you have these settings:

  • Menu icon > Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Under Web Content section
  • Select checkbox 'Accept cookies from sites'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Once you have posted info, the settings ect can be checked.

If this is not working as expected then I suggest you use a different set of server settings and also get an app specific password/secure mail key to use in Thunderbird.

  • Make sure all the stored passwords have been removed.
  • Create a secure mail key: https://www.att.com/support/article/email-support/KM1240308
  • Adjust server settings for the imap account.
  • Incoming server : imap.mail.att.net
  • Port: 993
  • Connection SEcurity: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method : Normal Password
  • User Name: full @sbcglobal.net email address


  • Outgoing server : smtp.mail.att.net
  • Port: 587
  • Connection SEcurity: STARTTLS
  • Authentication Method : Normal Password
  • User Name: full @sbcglobal.net email address

When prompted for password you enter the 'Secure mail key' password.
creator: Toad-Hall

creator: wsmwk

content:
How do I say this nicely. I can't. ATT are idiots.

First and foremost they have been pushing an oauth authentication model for almost 10 years and still have not completed the process of getting a "secret" upon which the process relies. So your stuck with using a mailkey See https://www.att.com/support/article/email-support/KM1240308/

Then you could manually configure your account as a yahoo one only leaving the username as your full ATT email address and use oauth authentication. That works because they contract the service from Yahoo, and Yahoo do have an oAuth secret. Yahoo publish the setting needed here https://help.yahoo.com/kb/SLN4075.html and an app password is not required if authentication is set to oauth.

BTW, when you get mail, there are no "Thunderbird" servers. There is Thunderbird, a program running on your computer trying to connect to ATT/Yahoo using the rather shody instructions ATT provide. Apparently the humans involved in their support script reading are no better than the written instructions they are provided.

Things that do not work eve by default;

  • Your ATT password, except to create a mailkey or to initially authenticate to Yahoo and obtain an oAuth token.
  • Automatic configuration in Thunderbird. As the ATT/Yahoo process requires a mailkey not a password the automatic configuration will work, if you know you need to have the mailkey first.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Le cartelle personalizzate sono accessibili in Thunderbird solo se l'account è stato configurato per usare IMAP (non basta cambiare i server, l'account deve essere stato configurato per IMAP).

Se stai già usando IMAP vedi qui: https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/sincronizzazione-imap#w_configurazione-della-sincronizzazione-ed-utilizzo-dello-spazio-sul-disco

Se invece l'account è di tipo POP3, valuta se ti conviene fare la conversione: https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/passare-da-account-pop-a-imap
